  content: '';
  background: #66BB6A;
}
@media print {
  .edit_mode div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  .prompt {
    text-align: left;
  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: #f7f7f7;
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is
   to make sure that empty JavaScript output_subareas have no height. */
div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}
div.unrecognized_cell {
  padding: 5px 5px 5px 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;

  /* Modern browsers */

div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell {

div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a:hover {

}

div.input {

/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_prompt {

  border-top: 1px solid transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight {
  margin: 0.4em;
  border: none;

  background-color: transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight > pre {
  margin: 0px;

  background-color: transparent;

/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;
 * }
 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;
  overflow-x: auto;
}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  /* Note that this should set vertical padding only, since CodeMirror assumes
       that horizontal padding will be set on CodeMirror pre */
  padding: 0.4em 0;
}
.CodeMirror-linenumber {
  padding: 0 8px 0 4px;
}
.CodeMirror-gutters {
  border-bottom-left-radius: 2px;
  border-top-left-radius: 2px;
}
.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. This sets horizontal padding only,
    use .CodeMirror-lines for vertical */
  padding: 0 0.4em;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;
}
.CodeMirror-cursor {
  border-left: 1.4px solid black;
}
@media screen and (min-width: 2138px) and (max-width: 4319px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 2px solid black;
  }
}
@media screen and (min-width: 4320px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 4px solid black;
  }
}

div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}
/* This class is the outer container of all output sections. */
div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;
  page-break-inside: avoid;

  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;

div.output_area 
div.output_area

  max-width: 100%;

}
div.output_area img.unconfined,
div.output_area svg.unconfined {
  max-width: none;
}
div.output_area .mglyph > img {
  max-width: none;
}
/* This is needed to protect the pre formating from global settings such
   as that of bootstrap */
.output {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;

  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;

  div.output_area {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */

    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
div.output_area pre {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 1px 0 1px 0;
  border: 0;
  vertical-align: baseline;
  color: black;
  background-color: transparent;
  border-radius: 0;
}
/* This class is for the output subarea inside the output_area and after
   the prompt div. */
div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: auto;
  padding: 0.4em;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
  max-width: calc(100% - 14ex);
}
div.output_scroll div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: visible;
}
/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different
   output types */
/* all text output has this class: */
div.output_text {
  text-align: left;
  color: #000;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */
div.output_stderr {
  background: #fdd;
  /* very light red background for stderr */
}
div.output_latex {
  text-align: left;
}
/* Empty output_javascript divs should have no height */
div.output_javascript:empty {
  padding: 0;
}
.js-error {
  color: darkred;
}
/* raw_input styles */

.highlight .il { color: #666666 } /* Literal.Number.Integer.Long */</style><div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Proving-Convexity-of-Mean-Squared-Error-Loss---Case-Study">Proving Convexity of Mean Squared Error Loss - Case Study<a class="anchor-link" href="#Proving-Convexity-of-Mean-Squared-Error-Loss---Case-Study">¶</a></h2><ul>
<li>In this blog post, we shall quickly cover the convexity proof for Mean Squared Error Loss function used in a traditional Regression setting.</li>
<li>In case you haven't checked out my previous blog - <a href="https://jadhavpritish.github.io/2019/08/The%20Curious%20Case%20of%20Convex%20Functions.html">The Curious Case of Convex Functions</a>, I would highly recommend you to check it out. The blog focuses on all the basic building blocks for proving convexity. </li>
</ul>
<p>With that in mind, let us start by reviewing -</p>
<ol>
<li>The MSE loss for a Regression Algorithm.</li>
<li>Conditions for checking Convexity. </li>
</ol>
<h3 id="1.-MSE-Loss-Function--">1. MSE Loss Function -<a class="anchor-link" href="#1.-MSE-Loss-Function--">¶</a></h3><p>The MSE loss function in a Regression setting is defined as -</p>
$$
\begin{align}
J(W) = \frac{1}{2m}\sum_{i=1}^{m} [y^{(i)} - \hat{y}^{(i)}]^2 \tag{1}
\end{align}
$$<p>Where,</p>
<center>
m = number of training examples.<br>
$J(w)$ = Loss as a function of Regression Coeffients. <br>
$y^{(i)}$ = true value for the $ith$ training example. <br>
$\hat{y}^{(i)}$ = predicted value for the $ith$ training example.<br>
</center><p>For $ith$ training example, $\hat{y}^{(i)}$ is defined as -</p>
$$
\begin{align}
\hat{y}^{(i)} =  \sum_{j = 1}^{n}(w_jx_{j}^{(i)} ) \tag{2}
\end{align}
$$<p>Where,</p>
<center>
n = number of features.<br>
</center><p>For the sake of convenience/readability, <strong>let's assume n = 3</strong>. The eq.(2) can thus be written as -</p>
$$
\begin{align}
\hat{y}^{(i)} &= \sum_{j = 1}^{n}(w_jx_{j}^{(i)} )
\\
& = w_1x_{1}^{(i)} + w_2x_{2}^{(i)} + w_3x_{3}^{(i)} \tag{3}
\end{align}
$$<p>Since we have considered only one training example, we can let go of the training index.</p>
$$
\begin{align}
\therefore J(W) = \frac{1}{2} [y - (w_1x_{1} + w_2x_{2} + w_3x_{3})]^2 \tag{4}
\end{align}
$$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="2.-Checking-for-Convexity-of-J(W)-">2. Checking for Convexity of J(W)-<a class="anchor-link" href="#2.-Checking-for-Convexity-of-J(W)-">¶</a></h3><p>For checking the convexity of Mean-Squared-Error function, we shall perform the following checks -</p>
<ul>
<li>Step 1 - Computing the Hessian of J(W)</li>
<li>Step 2- Computing the Principal Minors of the Hessian.</li>
<li>Step 3 - Based on the values of principal minors, determine the definiteness of Hessian. </li>
<li>Step 4 - Comment on Convexity based on convexity tests. </li>
</ul>
<p>Let us get down to it right away-</p>
<h4 id="Step-1---Hessian-of-$J(w)$--">Step 1 - Hessian of $J(w)$ -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Step-1---Hessian-of-$J(w)$--">¶</a></h4>$$
\begin{align}
J^H = \begin{bmatrix} 
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_1^2} & 
\frac{\partial^2 J}{\partial w_1 \partial w_2} &
\frac{\partial^2 J}{\partial w_1 \partial w_3} & \\
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_2 \partial w_1} & 
\frac{\partial^2 J}{\partial {w_2}^2 } &
\frac{\partial^2 J}{\partial w_2 \partial w_3} \\
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_3 \partial w_1} & 
\frac{\partial^2 J}{\partial w_3 \partial w_2 } &
\frac{\partial^2 J}{\partial {w_3}^2 } \\
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align}
$$<p>Lets compute each component of the matrix.</p>
$$
\begin{align}
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_1^2} &= \frac{\partial}{\partial w_1} \big[ \frac{\partial}{\partial w_1}\big[\frac{1}{2} [y - (w_1x_{1} + w_2x_{2} + w_3x_{3})]^2\big] \big]
\\
&= \frac{\partial}{\partial w_1} [y - (w_1x_{1} + w_2x_{2} + w_3x_{3})](-x_1)
\\
&= (-x_1)(-x_1)
\\
&= (x_1)^2
\end{align}
$$$$
\begin{align}
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_1w_2} &= \frac{\partial}{\partial w_1} \big[ \frac{\partial}{\partial w_2}\big[\frac{1}{2} [y - (w_1x_{1} + w_2x_{2} + w_3x_{3})]^2\big] \big]
\\
&= \frac{\partial}{\partial w_1}[y - (w_1x_{1} + w_2x_{2} + w_3x_{3})](-x_2)
\\
& = (-x_2)(-x_1)
\\
& = x_1x_2
\\
&= \frac{\partial ^2 J}{w_2w_1}
\end{align}
$$<p>Similarly, it can be proven that -</p>
$$
\begin{align}
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_1w_3} = \frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_3w_1} = x_1x_3 \\
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_2w_3} = \frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_3w_2} = x_2x_3 \\
\end{align}
$$$$
\begin{align}
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_2^2} = x_2^2 \\
\frac{\partial ^2 J}{\partial w_3^2} = x_3^2 
\end{align}
$$$$
\begin{align}
\therefore J^H = \begin{bmatrix} 
x_1^2 & 
x_1x_2 &
x_1x_3 & \\
x_2x_1 & 
x_2^2 &
x_2x_3 \\
x_3x_1 & 
x_3x_2 &
x_3^2 \\
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align}
$$
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Step-2---Computing-the-Principal-Minors---">Step 2 - Computing the Principal Minors  -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Step-2---Computing-the-Principal-Minors---">¶</a></h4><p>From <a href="https://jadhavpritish.github.io/2019/08/The%20Curious%20Case%20of%20Convex%20Functions.html">previous blog post</a>, a function is convex if all the principal minors are greater than or equal to zero i.e. $\bigtriangleup_k$ $\geq 0 \;\; \forall$ k .</p>
<h5 id="compute-$\bigtriangleup_1$---">compute $\bigtriangleup_1$  -<a class="anchor-link" href="#compute-$\bigtriangleup_1$---">¶</a></h5><p>Principal Minors of order 1 ($\bigtriangleup_1$) can be obtained by deleting any 3-1 = 2 rows and corresponding columns.</p>
<p>a. By deleting row 2 and 3 along with corresponding columns
$ \bigtriangleup_1 $ = x_1^2</p>
<p>b. By deleting row 1 and 3 along with corresponding columns
$ \bigtriangleup_1 $ = x_2^2</p>
<p>c. By deleting row 1 and 2 along with corresponding columns
$ \bigtriangleup_1 $ = x_3^2</p>
<h5 id="compute-$\bigtriangleup_2$---">compute $\bigtriangleup_2$  -<a class="anchor-link" href="#compute-$\bigtriangleup_2$---">¶</a></h5><p>Principal Minors of order 2 can be obtained by deleting any 3-2 = 1 row and corresponding column.</p>
<p>a. By deleting row 1 and corresponding column 1 - <br></p>
$$
\begin{align}
\bigtriangleup_2 & = \begin{vmatrix}
x_2^2 & x_2x_3 \\
x_3x_2 & x_3^2
\end{vmatrix} \\
& = x_2^2x_3^2 - (x_2x_3)(x_3x_2) \\
& = x_2^2x_3^2 - x_2^2x_3^2 \\
& = 0 
\end{align}
$$<p>b. By deleting row 2 and corresponding column 2
$$
\begin{align}
\bigtriangleup_2 & = \begin{vmatrix}
x_1^2 & x_1x_3 \\
x_3x_1 & x_3^2
\end{vmatrix} \\
& = x_1^2x_3^2 - (x_1x_3)(x_3x_1) \\
& = x_1^2x_3^2 - x_1^2x_3^2 \\
& = 0 
\end{align}
$$</p>
<p>c. By deleting row 3 and corresponding column 3
$$
\begin{align}
\bigtriangleup_2 & = \begin{vmatrix}
x_1^2 & x_1x_2 \\
x_2x_1 & x_2^2
\end{vmatrix} \\
& = x_1^2x_2^2 - (x_1x_2)(x_2x_1) \\
& = x_1^2x_2^2 - x_1^2x_2^2 \\
& = 0 
\end{align}
$$</p>
<h5 id="compute-$\bigtriangleup_3$---">compute $\bigtriangleup_3$  -<a class="anchor-link" href="#compute-$\bigtriangleup_3$---">¶</a></h5><p>Principal Minors of order 3 can be obtained by computing determinant of J(W).</p>
$$
\begin{align}
\bigtriangleup_3 & = \begin{vmatrix}J^H \end{vmatrix} 
\\
&= \begin{vmatrix} 
x_1^2 & x_1x_2 & x_1x_3 & \\
x_2x_1 & 
x_2^2 &
x_2x_3 \\
x_3x_1 & 
x_3x_2 &
x_3^2 \\
\end{vmatrix}\\
&= x_1^2 * (x_2^2x_3^2 - x_2^2x_3^2) - x_1x_2 * (x_1x_2x_3^2 - x_1x_2x_3^2) + x_1x_3(x_1x_2^2x_3 - x_1x_2^2x_3) \\
&= 0 
\end{align}
$$<h4 id="Step-3---Comment-on-Definiteness-of-Hessian-of-J(w)--">Step 3 - Comment on Definiteness of Hessian of J(w) -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Step-3---Comment-on-Definiteness-of-Hessian-of-J(w)--">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li>The principal minors of order 1 have a squared form. We know that a squared function is always positive. </li>
<li>The principal minors of order 2 and 3 are equal zero. </li>
<li>It can be concluded that $\bigtriangleup_k \geq 0 \;\; \forall k$</li>
<li>Hence the Hessian of J(w) is Positive Semidefinite. </li>
</ul>
<h4 id="Step-4-Comment-on-convexity--">Step 4 Comment on convexity -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Step-4-Comment-on-convexity--">¶</a></h4><p>Before we comment on the convexity of J(W), let's revise the conditions for convexity -</p>
<p>If $X^H$ is the Hessian Matrix of f(x) then -</p>
<ul>
<li>f(x) is <strong>strictly convex</strong> in $S$ if $X^H$ is a Postive Definite Matrix. </li>
<li>f(x) is <strong>convex</strong> in $S$ if $X^H$ is a Postive Semi-Definite Matrix. </li>
<li>f(x) is <strong>strictly concave</strong> in $S$ if $X^H$ is a Negative Definite Matrix. </li>
<li>f(x) is <strong>concave</strong> in $S$ if $X^H$ is a Negative Semi-Definite Matrix.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Since the Hessian of J(w) is Positive Semidefinite, it can be concluded that the function J(w) is convex.</strong></p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Final-Comments--">Final Comments -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Final-Comments--">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>This blog post is aimed at proving the convexity of MSE loss function in a Regression setting by simplifying the problem. </li>
<li>There are different ways of proving the convexity but I found this easier to comprehend. </li>
<li>Feel free to try out the process for different loss functions that you may have encountered. </li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>

entry.title: The Curious Case of Convex Functions
entry.id: tag:None,2019-08-24:/The Curious Case of Convex Functions.html
entry.summary: The convexity property of a function unlocks a crucial advantage where the local minima of a convex function is also a global minima. This ensures that a model can be trained where the loss function is minimized to its globally minimum value. In this blog post, we shall work through the concepts needed to prove the convexity of a function.
entry.content:
<style type="text/css">/*!
*
* IPython notebook
*
*/
/* CSS font colors for translated ANSI escape sequences */
/* The color values are a mix of
   http://www.xcolors.net/dl/baskerville-ivorylight and
   http://www.xcolors.net/dl/euphrasia */
.ansi-black-fg {
  color: #3E424D;

div.cell {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  border-radius: 2px;
  box-sizing: border-box;
  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;
  -webkit-box-sizing: border-box;
  border-width: 1px;
  border-style: solid;
  border-color: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  padding: 5px;
  /* This acts as a spacer between cells, that is outside the border */
  margin: 0px;
  outline: none;
  position: relative;
  overflow: visible;
}
div.cell:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: transparent;
}
div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-left-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  border-right-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-right-width: 1px;
  background: #E3F2FD;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
div.cell.selected,
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-color: #ababab;
}
div.cell.selected:before,
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: #42A5F5;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.selected,
  div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected {
  border-color: #66BB6A;
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: #66BB6A;
}
@media print {
  .edit_mode div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  .prompt {
    text-align: left;
  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: #f7f7f7;
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is
   to make sure that empty JavaScript output_subareas have no height. */
div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}
div.unrecognized_cell {
  padding: 5px 5px 5px 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell {
  border-radius: 2px;
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  background: #eaeaea;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.unrecognized_cell > div.prompt {
    display: none;
  }
}
div.code_cell {
  /* avoid page breaking on code cells when printing */
}
@media print {
  div.code_cell {
    page-break-inside: avoid;
  }
}
/* any special styling for code cells that are currently running goes here */
div.input {
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.input {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_prompt {
  color: #303F9F;
  border-top: 1px solid transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight {
  margin: 0.4em;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight > pre {
  margin: 0px;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;
 * }
 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;
  overflow-x: auto;
}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  /* Note that this should set vertical padding only, since CodeMirror assumes
       that horizontal padding will be set on CodeMirror pre */
  padding: 0.4em 0;
}
.CodeMirror-linenumber {
  padding: 0 8px 0 4px;
}
.CodeMirror-gutters {
  border-bottom-left-radius: 2px;
  border-top-left-radius: 2px;
}
.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. This sets horizontal padding only,
    use .CodeMirror-lines for vertical */
  padding: 0 0.4em;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;
}
.CodeMirror-cursor {
  border-left: 1.4px solid black;
}
@media screen and (min-width: 2138px) and (max-width: 4319px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 2px solid black;
  }
}
@media screen and (min-width: 4320px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 4px solid black;
  }
}

div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}
/* This class is the outer container of all output sections. */
div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.output_area .MathJax_Display {
  text-align: left !important;
}
div.output_area 
div.output_area 
div.output_area img,
div.output_area svg {
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}
div.output_area img.unconfined,
div.output_area svg.unconfined {
  max-width: none;
}
div.output_area .mglyph > img {
  max-width: none;
}
/* This is needed to protect the pre formating from global settings such
   as that of bootstrap */
.output {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.output_area {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
div.output_area pre {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 1px 0 1px 0;
  border: 0;
  vertical-align: baseline;
  color: black;
  background-color: transparent;
  border-radius: 0;
}
/* This class is for the output subarea inside the output_area and after
   the prompt div. */
div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: auto;
  padding: 0.4em;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
  max-width: calc(100% - 14ex);
}
div.output_scroll div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: visible;
}
/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different
   output types */
/* all text output has this class: */
div.output_text {
  text-align: left;
  color: #000;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */
div.output_stderr {
  background: #fdd;
  /* very light red background for stderr */
}
div.output_latex {
  text-align: left;
}
/* Empty output_javascript divs should have no height */
div.output_javascript:empty {
  padding: 0;
}
.js-error {
  color: darkred;
}
/* raw_input styles */
div.raw_input_container {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  padding-top: 5px;
}
pre.raw_input_prompt {
  /* nothing needed here. */
}
input.raw_input {
  font-family: monospace;
  font-size: inherit;
  color: inherit;
  width: auto;
  /* make sure input baseline aligns with prompt */
  vertical-align: baseline;
  /* padding + margin = 0.5em between prompt and cursor */
  padding: 0em 0.25em;
  margin: 0em 0.25em;
}
input.raw_input:focus {
  box-shadow: none;
}
p.p-space {
  margin-bottom: 10px;
}
div.output_unrecognized {
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
}
div.output_unrecognized a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.output_unrecognized a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
.rendered_html {
  color: #000;
  /* any extras will just be numbers: */
}



.rendered_html :link {
  text-decoration: underline;
}
.rendered_html :visited {
  text-decoration: underline;
}






.rendered_html h1:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.538em;
}
.rendered_html h2:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.636em;
}
.rendered_html h3:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.777em;
}
.rendered_html h4:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html h5:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html h6:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html ul:not(.list-inline),
.rendered_html ol:not(.list-inline) {
  padding-left: 2em;
}








.rendered_html * + ul {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html * + ol {
  margin-top: 1em;
}





.rendered_html pre,




.rendered_html tr,
.rendered_html th,


.rendered_html tbody tr:nth-child(odd) {
  background: #f5f5f5;
}
.rendered_html tbody tr:hover {
  background: rgba(66, 165, 245, 0.2);
}

.highlight .il { color: #666666 } /* Literal.Number.Integer.Long */</style><div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="The-Curious-Case-of-Convex-Functions">The Curious Case of Convex Functions<a class="anchor-link" href="#The-Curious-Case-of-Convex-Functions">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>Most of the introductory courses for Machine Learning cover algorithms like Linear Regression and Logistic Regression with varying degrees of detail.</li>
<li>The resources are plentiful for grasping the nitty gitties involved. However, I rarely found traditional courses diving into proving the convexity of MSE loss function. </li>
<li>Most of the online resources often skim through the part where they define the cost function for Regression Algorithms using MSE where the cost function is claimed to be a convex function. </li>
<li>The convexity property unlocks a crucial advantage where the local minima of a convex function is also a global minima.</li>
<li>This ensures that a model can be trained where the loss function is minimized to its globally minimum value. </li>
</ul>
<p><br>
<img src="../../images/convex_functions/convex_function_image.png"> <br></p>
<h3 id="Proving-Convexity--">Proving Convexity -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Proving-Convexity--">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>In this blog post, we shall work through the concepts needed to prove the convexity of a function. </li>
<li>So hang in tight and by the end of this article, you would have a better understanding of - </li>
</ul>
<p>a. Symmetric Matrices. <br>
b. Hessian Matrices. <br>
c. Postive and Negative Definite/Semidefinite Matrices. <br>
d. Proving convexity of functions. <br></p>
<p>Without much further ado, let's jump into it.</p>
<h3 id="Basics-of-Matrices--">Basics of Matrices -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Basics-of-Matrices--">¶</a></h3><p>We shall touch base on some of the basic concepts in Matrices that will help us in proving the convexity of a function. These basics are typically covered in Undergraduate Courses and should sound familiar to you.</p>
<p><u><b> 1. Square Matrix - </b></u></p>
<p>Given a matrix X of dimensions $m \times n$, X is a square matrix iff (if and only if) m = n. In other words, A matrix 'X' is called a square matrix if the number of matrix rows is equal to the number of columns.</p>
$$
\begin{align} 
X = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 8 & 9 & 10 \end{bmatrix}_{3 \times 3} 
\end{align}
$$<p>In the above example, since the number of rows (m) = number of columns (3),<b> X can be termed as a square matrix. </b></p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [108]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">## basic python imports</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="kn">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">IPython.core.display</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">display</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="n">HTML</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.datasets</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">make_spd_matrix</span>

<span class="n">display</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">HTML</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'<style>.prompt{width: 0px; min-width: 0px; visibility: collapse}</style>'</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">display</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">HTML</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"<style>.container { width:100% !important; }</style>"</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<style>.prompt{width: 0px; min-width: 0px; visibility: collapse}</style>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea ">
<style>.container { width:100% !important; }</style>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [109]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">### python function for checking whether a matrix is a square matrix. </span>


<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">check_square_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">):</span>
    
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">shape</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]:</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="bp">True</span>
    <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="bp">False</span>
        
    
<span class="n">A</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">B</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randn</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Is Matrix A a Square Matrix: - {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">check_square_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">A</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Is Matrix B a Square Matrix  - {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">check_square_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">B</span><span class="p">)))</span>
      
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Is Matrix A a Square Matrix: - True
Is Matrix B a Square Matrix  - False
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="2.-Symmetric-Matrix--">2. Symmetric Matrix -<a class="anchor-link" href="#2.-Symmetric-Matrix--">¶</a></h3><p>A <b>square</b> matrix 'X' is termed as symmetric if $x_{ij} = x_{ji}$ for all i and j where i, j denotes the ith row and jth column respectively. In other words, a matrix X is syemmetric if the transpose of X if equal to matrix X.</p>
<p>i.e, 
$$
\begin{align}
X^T = X
\end{align}
$$</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [110]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">## function for checking if a matrix is symmetric</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">check_symmetry</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">check_square_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">transpose</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">all</span><span class="p">():</span>
            <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"is a Symmetric Matrix"</span>
        <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"not a Symmetric Matrix"</span>
    <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"not a Symmetric Matrix since it is not Square Matrix"</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [111]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">## pseudo generate a symmetric matrix </span>

<span class="n">base_matrix</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">SA</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">base_matrix</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">base_matrix</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix A - </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">SA</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="c1">## generate a random matrix</span>
<span class="n">SB</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix B - </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">SB</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">SC</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix C - </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">SC</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Matrix A - 
 [[34 16 12]
 [16 10 21]
 [12 21 18]]
Matrix B - 
 [[19  2 18]
 [15  3 17]
 [ 8 15 17]]
Matrix C - 
 [[ 0  4  8  0  6  6  4  9  8  0]
 [ 0  1  9 17  6  0  6  8  9  8]]
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [112]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Is Matrix A {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">check_symmetry</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">SA</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Is Matrix B {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">check_symmetry</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">SB</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Is Matrix C {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">check_symmetry</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">SC</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Is Matrix A is a Symmetric Matrix
Is Matrix B not a Symmetric Matrix
Is Matrix C not a Symmetric Matrix since it is not Square Matrix
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="3.-Hermitian-Matrix--">3. Hermitian Matrix -<a class="anchor-link" href="#3.-Hermitian-Matrix--">¶</a></h3><p>A square matrix X is self-adjoint or a Hermitian matrix if -</p>
$$
\begin{align}
\overline{X^{T}} = X = X^{H}
\end{align}
$$<p>Note that the terms <strong>self-adjoint and Hermitian can be used interchangeably</strong>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [113]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">check_hermitian</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">):</span>
    
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">check_square_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">conjugate</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">transpose</span><span class="p">())</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">all</span><span class="p">():</span>
            <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"is a Hermitian Matrix"</span>
        <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"is not a Hermitian Matrix"</span>
    <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"is not a Hermitian Matrix since it is not a Square Matrix"</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [114]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">## pseudo generate a symmetric matrix </span>

<span class="c1">##generate a random complex matrix with entries between -20 and 10.</span>
<span class="n">base_matrix</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="c1">## trick to force symmetric nature</span>
<span class="n">HA</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">base_matrix</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">conjugate</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">base_matrix</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">T</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix A - </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">HA</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1">## generate a random complex matrix that is not symmetric</span>
<span class="n">HB</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix B - </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">HB</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">HC</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">))</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mi">1j</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">randint</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix C - </span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2"> {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">HC</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Is Matrix A {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">check_hermitian</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">HA</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Is Matrix B {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">check_hermitian</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">HB</span><span class="p">)))</span>
<span class="k">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Is Matrix C {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">check_hermitian</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">HC</span><span class="p">)))</span>
</pre></div>

Is Matrix B is not a Hermitian Matrix

</pre>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="4.-Hessian-Matrix--">4. Hessian Matrix -<a class="anchor-link" href="#4.-Hessian-Matrix--">¶</a></h3><p>The Hessian of a multivariate function $f(x_1, x_2, ...x_n)$ is a way for organizing second-order partial derivatives in the form of a matrix.</p>
<p>Consider a multivariate fucntion $ f(x_1, x_2, ...x_n) $ then its Hessian can be defined as follows -</p>
$$
\begin{align}
H_f = \begin{bmatrix} 
\frac{\partial ^2 f}{\partial x_1^2} & 
\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1 \partial x_2} &
\cdots &
\frac{\partial ^2 f}{\partial x_1 \partial x_n} \\
\frac{\partial ^2 f}{\partial x_2 \partial x_1} & 
\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial {x_2}^2 } &
\cdots &
\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_2 \partial x_n} \\
\vdots &  \ddots & \cdots & \vdots\\
\frac{\partial ^2 f}{\partial x_n \partial x_1} & 
\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_n \partial x_2 } &
\cdots &
\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial {x_n}^2 } \\
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align}
$$<p>Note that a Hessian matrix by definition is a Square and Symmetric matrix.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="5.-Positive-Definite-and-Semidefinte-Matrices--">5. Positive Definite and Semidefinte Matrices -<a class="anchor-link" href="#5.-Positive-Definite-and-Semidefinte-Matrices--">¶</a></h3><p>You may have seen references about these matrices at multiple places but the definition and ways to prove definitiveness remains elusive to many. Let us start with the text definition -</p>
\begin{align}
A \; n \times n \; square \; matrix \; X \; is \; Postive \; Definite \; if \;\;\; a^TXa \; > \; 0 \; \forall a \; \in \; \mathbb R^n.
\end{align}<p>Similarly,</p>
\begin{align}
A \; n \times n \; square \; matrix \; X \; is \; Postive \; Semidefinite \; if \;\; a^TXa \geq 0 \; \forall \; a \in \; \mathbb R^n. 
\end{align}<p>The same logic can be easily extended to Negative Definite and Negative Semidefinite matrices.</p>
\begin{align}
A \; n \times n \; square \; matrix \; X \; is \; Negative \; Definite \; if \;\; a^TXa \; < \; 0 \; \forall a \; \in \; \mathbb R^n.
\end{align}<p>And finally, <br></p>
\begin{align}
A \; n \times n \; square \; matrix \; X \; is \; Negative \; Semidefinite \; if \;\; a^TXa \leq 0 \; \forall \; a \in \; \mathbb R^n. 
\end{align}<ul>
<li>However, while checking for Matrix Definiteness, manually validating the condition of every value of x is definitely not an option. </li>
<li>So let us try and break this down even further.</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Eigen-Values-and-Eigen-Vector--">Eigen Values and Eigen Vector -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Eigen-Values-and-Eigen-Vector--">¶</a></h3><p>We know that an eigenvector is a vector whose direction remains unchanged when a linear transformation is applied to it.</p>
<p>Mathematically,</p>
$$
\begin{align}
Xa = \lambda a \tag{1}
\end{align}
$$<p>Where, 
$\lambda $ represents a scalar called the eigenvalue. This simply means that the linear transformation X on a can be completely defined by $\lambda $.</p>
<p>pre-multiplying eq.(1) by $a^T$ gives -</p>
$$
\begin{align}
a^TXa = a^T \lambda a \tag{2}
\end{align}
$$<p>since $\lambda $ in eq.(2) is a scalar we can write eq.(2) as - 
$$
\begin{align}
a^TXa = \lambda a^T a = \lambda <a, a> \tag{3}
\end{align}
$$
where, <br>
$<x, y>$ represent the dot product, $x^Ty$</p>
<h3 id="Analysis">Analysis<a class="anchor-link" href="#Analysis">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>It is easy to see that the dot product of a with $a^T$ will always be positive. </li>
<li>Referring back to the definition of positive definite matrix and eq(3), $a^TXa$ can be greater than zero if and only if $\lambda$ is greater than zero. </li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Derived-Definition-for-Matrix-Definiteness--">Derived Definition for Matrix Definiteness -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Derived-Definition-for-Matrix-Definiteness--">¶</a></h3><p>Based on pointers mentioned in above Analysis we can tweak the formal definitions of Matrix Definiteness as follows -</p>
<ol>
<li>A Symmetric Matrix 'X' is Positive Definite if $\lambda_{i} > \; 0 \;\; \forall i$</li>
<li>A Symmetric Matrix 'X' is Positive Semi-Definite if $\lambda_{i} \geq \; 0 \;\; \forall i$</li>
<li>A Symmetric Matrix 'X' is Negative Definite if $\lambda_{i} < \; 0 \;\; \forall i$</li>
<li>A Symmetric Matrix 'X' is Negative Semi-Definite if $\lambda_{i} \leq \; 0 \;\; \forall i$</li>
</ol>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [116]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">### computing eigen values in python - </span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">compute_eigen_values</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">eigen_values</span><span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linalg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">eigvals</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">eigen_values</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">check_definiteness</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">eigen_values</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">eigen_values</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">all</span><span class="p">():</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix is Postive Definite as well as Positive Semidefinite"</span>
    <span class="k">elif</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">eigen_values</span> <span class="o">>=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">all</span><span class="p">():</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix is Postive Semi Definite only"</span>
    <span class="k">elif</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">eigen_values</span> <span class="o"><</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">all</span><span class="p">():</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix is Negative Definite as well as Negative Semidefinite"</span>
    <span class="k">elif</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">eigen_values</span> <span class="o"><=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">all</span><span class="p">():</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix is Negative SemiDefinite"</span>
    <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="s2">"Matrix is neither positive definite nor negative definite"</span>
    
<span class="n">base_eig_matrix</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">make_spd_matrix</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">EA</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">base_eig_matrix</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">base_eig_matrix</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">transpose</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">ea_eigen_values</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">compute_eigen_values</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">EA</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Eigen values are </span><span class="si">%s</span><span class="s2">"</span><span class="o">%</span><span class="k">ea_eigen_values</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">check_definiteness</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ea_eigen_values</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Eigen values are [6.54206241 0.08543726 0.82923445]
Matrix is Postive Definite as well as Positive Semidefinite
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Alternate Definition for Dtermining Matrix Defniteness -</p>
<ol>
<li>Computing Eigen values for large matrices often involves solving linear equations. </li>
<li>Large Matrices will will involve solving linear equations in large number of variables. </li>
<li>Hence, It may not always to be feasible to solve for Eigen Values.</li>
</ol>
<p>An Alternate Theorem for Determing Defniteness of Matrices comes to the rescue -</p>
<h3 id="Theorem--">Theorem -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Theorem--">¶</a></h3><ol>
<li>A Symmetric Matrix 'X' is Positive Definite if $D_k > \; 0 \;\; \forall k$ Where, $D_k$ represents the kth <strong>Leading Principal Minor.</strong></li>
<li>A Symmetric Matrix 'X' is Positive Semi-Definite if $\bigtriangleup_k \geq \; 0 \;\; \forall k$ Where, $\bigtriangleup_k$ represents the kth <strong>Principal Minor.</strong> </li>
<li>A Symmetric Matrix 'X' is Negative Definite if $D_k < \; 0 \;\; \forall k$ Where, $D_k$ represents the kth <strong>Leading Principal Minor.</strong></li>
<li>A Symmetric Matrix 'X' is Negative Semi-Definite if $\bigtriangleup_k \leq \; 0 \;\; \forall k$ Where, $\bigtriangleup_k$ represents the kth <strong>Principal Minor.</strong> </li>
</ol>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Principal-Minors-of-a-Matrix--">Principal Minors of a Matrix -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Principal-Minors-of-a-Matrix--">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>For a Square Matrix X, a Pricipal Submatrix of order k is obtained by deleting <strong>any</strong> (n-k) rows and corresponding (n-k) columns. </li>
<li>The determinant of such a Pricipal Submatrix is called as the Principal Minor of matrix X. </li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Leading-Principal-Minors-of-a-Matrix--">Leading Principal Minors of a Matrix -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Leading-Principal-Minors-of-a-Matrix--">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>For a Square Matrix X, a Leading Pricipal Submatrix of order k is obtained by deleting <strong>last</strong> (n-k) rows and corresponding (n-k) columns. </li>
<li>The determinant of such a Leading Pricipal Submatrix is called as the Leading Principal Minor of matrix X. </li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Proving-/-Checking-Convexity-of-a-function--">Proving / Checking Convexity of a function -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Proving-/-Checking-Convexity-of-a-function--">¶</a></h3><p>With all the relevant definitions and theorem covered in previous sections, we are now ready to define checks for determining the convexity of functions.</p>
<p>A function f(x) defined over n variables on an open convex set $S$ can be tested for convexity using following criteria -</p>
<p>If $X^H$ is the Hessian Matrix of f(x) then -</p>
<ul>
<li>f(x) is <strong>strictly convex</strong> in $S$ if $X^H$ is a Postive Definite Matrix. </li>
<li>f(x) is <strong>convex</strong> in $S$ if $X^H$ is a Postive Semi-Definite Matrix. </li>
<li>f(x) is <strong>strictly concave</strong> in $S$ if $X^H$ is a Negative Definite Matrix. </li>
<li>f(x) is <strong>concave</strong> in $S$ if $X^H$ is a Negative Semi-Definite Matrix.</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Example--">Example -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Example--">¶</a></h3><p>Consider an equation of Quadratic form -</p>
$$
\begin{align}
f(x_1, x_2, x_3) = 5x_1^2 - 2x_1x_2 + 2x_2^2 + x_3x_2 + x_3^2
\end{align}
$$<h3 id="STEP-1---Computing-the-Hessian">STEP 1 - Computing the Hessian<a class="anchor-link" href="#STEP-1---Computing-the-Hessian">¶</a></h3><p>The Hessian of $f(x_1, x_2, x_3)$ can be defined as follows - 
$$
\begin{align}
X^H = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_1^2}} & \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_1x_2}} & \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_1x_3}} \\ 
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_2x_1}} & \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_2^2}} & \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_2x_3}} \\ 
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_3x_1}} & \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_3x_2}} & \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_3^2}} \\
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align}
$$</p>
\begin{align} \\
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_1^2}} & = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_1^2}}(5x_1^2 - 2x_1x_2 + 2x_2^2 + x_3x_2 + x_3^2) 
\\
& = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_1}}(10x_1  -2x_2)
\\
& = 10
\end{align}<p>Similarly,</p>
\begin{align} \\
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_1x_2}} & = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_1x_2}}(5x_1^2 - 2x_1x_2 + 2x_2^2 + x_3x_2 + x_3^2) 
\\
& = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_1}}(-2x1 + 4x_2 + 1)
\\
& = -2
\\
& = \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_2x_1}}
\end{align}\begin{align} \\
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_1x_3}} & = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_1x_3}}(5x_1^2 - 2x_1x_2 + 2x_2^2 + x_3x_2 + x_3^2) 
\\
& = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_1}}(1x_2 + 2x_3)
\\
& = 0
\\
& = \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_3x_1}}
\end{align}\begin{align} \\
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_2^2}} & = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_2^2}}(5x_1^2 - 2x_1x_2 + 2x_2^2 + x_3x_2 + x_3^2) 
\\
& = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_2}}(-2x_1 + 4x_2 + x_3)
\\
& = 4
\end{align}\begin{align} \\
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_2x_3}} & = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_2x_3}}(5x_1^2 - 2x_1x_2 + 2x_2^2 + x_3x_2 + x_3^2) 
\\
& = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x2}}(x_2 + 2x_3)
\\
& = 1
\\
& = \frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_3x_2}}
\end{align}\begin{align} \\
\frac{\partial{f^2}}{\partial{x_3^2}} & = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_3^2}}(5x_1^2 - 2x_1x_2 + 2x_2^2 + x_3x_2 + x_3^2) 
\\
& = \frac{\partial{}}{\partial{x_3}}(x_2 + 2x_3)
\\
& = 2
\end{align}$$
\begin{align}
X^H = \begin{bmatrix}10 & -2 & 0 \\ -2 & 4 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2\end{bmatrix}
\end{align}
$$<h3 id="Step-2---Compute-Leading-Principal-Minors--">Step 2 - Compute Leading Principal Minors -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Step-2---Compute-Leading-Principal-Minors--">¶</a></h3><p>for k = 3,  delete last (3-3) =0 rows and (3-3) = 0 columns
$$
\begin{align} \\
D_{k} & = D_{3} 
\\
&= \begin{vmatrix}10 & -2 & 0 \\ -2 & 4 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 \\ \end{vmatrix}
\\
& = 62
\end{align}
$$</p>
<p>for k = 2,  delete last (3-2) =1 rows and corresponding (3-2) = 1 columns
$$
\begin{align} \\
D_{k} & = D_{2} 
\\
&= \begin{vmatrix}10 & -2 \\ -2 & 4 \\ \end{vmatrix}
\\
& = 36
\end{align}
$$</p>
<p>for k = 1,  delete last (3-1) =2 rows and corresponding (3-1) = 2 columns
$$
\begin{align} \\
D_{k} & = D_{1} 
\\
& = D_1 
\\ 
&= \begin{vmatrix}10 \\ \end{vmatrix}
\\
& = 10
\end{align}
$$</p>
<p>Since $D_1  > 0 $, $D_2 >0 $ and $D_3 > 0$, Hessian of $f(x_1, x_2, x_3)$ is Positive Definite.</p>
<h3 id="Step-3---Comment-on-Convexity--">Step 3 - Comment on Convexity -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Step-3---Comment-on-Convexity--">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>Since Hessian of $f(x_1, x_2, x_3)$ is Positive Definite, the function is <strong>strictly convex.</strong></li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Properties-of-Convex-functions---">Properties of Convex functions  -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Properties-of-Convex-functions---">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>Constant functions of the form $f(x) = c$ are both convex and concave. </li>
<li>$f(x) = x$ is both convex and concave. </li>
<li>Functions of the form $f(x) = x^r$ with $r \geq 1$ are convex on the Interval $0 < x < \infty$ </li>
<li>Functions of the form $f(x) = x^r$ with $0 < r < 1$ are concave on the Interval $0 < x < \infty$ </li>
<li>The function $f(x) = \log{(x)}$ is concave on the interval $0 < x < \infty$ </li>
<li>The function $f(x) = e^{x}$ is convex everywhere. </li>
<li>If $f(x)$ is convex, then $g(x) = cf(x)$ is also convex for any positive value of c.</li>
<li>If $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are convex then their sum $h(x) = f(x) + g(x)$ is also convex. </li>
</ul>
<h3 id="Final-Comments----">Final Comments   -<a class="anchor-link" href="#Final-Comments----">¶</a></h3><ul>
<li>We have investigated convex functions in depth while studying different ways of proving convexity. </li>
<li>In the next part of the article, we shall prove convexity of MSE loss function used in linear regression. </li>
<li>Convex functions are easy to minimise thus resulting in its usage across research domains. </li>
<li>So, the next time you want to plug in a different loss function in place of MSE while training a linear regression model, you might as well check its convexity. </li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>References -</p>
<p>[1] <a href="https://www.visiondummy.com/2014/03/eigenvalues-eigenvectors/">Eigen Values and Eigen Vectors</a> <br>
[2] <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Definiteness_of_a_matrix">Formal Definitions for Matrix Definiteness</a> <br>
[3] <a href="https://www.dr-eriksen.no/teaching/GRA6035/2010/lecture5.pdf">Principal Minors and Hessian Matrix by Dr. Eivind Eriksen</a><br>
[4] <a href="https://www.purplemath.com/modules/minors.htm">Computing Minors and Cofactors</a><br>
[5] <a href="http://www.math.cmu.edu/~lohp/docs/math/mop2013/convexity-soln.pdf">Properties of convex functions</a></p>

</div>
</div>
</div>

entry.title: Training Classifier Using PyTorch - Detailed Example.
entry.id: tag:None,2019-06-26:/Training Classifier Using PyTorch - Detailed Example..html
entry.summary: As a part of "Getting Acquainted with Deep Learning Frameworks" series, in the article we shall explore Pytorch Library. Pytorch is a deep learning library developed by Facebook Researchers. The focus of this article will be to highlight the steps involved in training a multiclass classifier using Pytorch.

  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}
/* This class is the outer container of all output sections. */
div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;

}

}
div.output_area

}

}

}
/* This is needed to protect the pre formating from global settings such

.output {

  -webkit-box-align: stretch;

}
div.output_area pre {

/* This class is for the output subarea inside the output_area and after
   the prompt div. */

  /* Old browsers */

}

}
/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different
   output types */
/* all text output has this class: */
div.output_text {

}
/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */
